titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Arthur Liman Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Mike Strom

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:42

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, diaries, legal documents, speeches, writings, printed material, photographs, and audiovisual materials that document the career of Arthur Liman. The papers emphasize the 1987 Iran-Contra hearings but also document many of Liman's other professional activities, including the Attica Prison uprising investigation and the Michael Milken trial. The papers contain an extensive collection of audiotapes and videotapes featuring conversations with and interviews of Liman.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Original audiotapes and videotapes, as well as preservation masters and duplicating masters, may not be played. Consult the finding aid and/or a reference archivist to determine availability of a use copy or the process required to generate a use copy.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection with the exception of the Iran-Contra Diary, the copyright of which will transfer to Yale University on November 22, 2024. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user. Check deed of gift for a specific date in 2024.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Arthur L. Liman Papers (MS 1762). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in four series and one addition: Series I. Legal Papers, 1963-1995. Series II. Personal Papers and Photographs, 1950-1999. Series III. Writings, 1957-1998. Series IV. Audiovisual Materials, 1978-1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers document the career of Arthur Liman, primarily the period from the Iran-Contra investigation in 1987 until his death in 1997. The Iran-Contra diary and audiotapes are of particular interest as they provide insight into Liman's private thoughts during the hearings. A movie script Liman later wrote about Iran-Contra reflects his opinion about how the events took place. The collection offers a wide variety of visual resources, including photographs of Liman from the early 1950s through the 1990s. Videotapes in the collection include copies of many of Liman's television interviews concerning Iran-Contra. The correspondence in the collection offers little personal perspective and the papers include limited documentation of Liman's private practice or his law firm.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Arthur Liman was born on November 5, 1932, in New York City. He graduated from Harvard in 1954 with a B.A. degree and proceeded to Yale Law School, graduating first in his class in 1957. Over the next forty years, Liman worked in disparate arenas to build a distinguished legal career, combining numerous public assignments and a private practice that included representing some of the country's most prosperous individuals and corporations.

After leaving Yale Law School in 1957, Liman joined the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York City. In 1961, he left the firm to become an assistant United States attorney under Robert M. Morgenthau and developed expertise in business law. Liman continued in the field of business law upon his return to Paul, Weiss in 1963, specializing in cases involving securities fraud and other white-collar crimes. According to newspaper accounts and tributes from his friends and colleagues, Liman was known for his thorough preparation and extraordinary commitment to his clients and was considered one of the best trial lawyers of his time. As a result, he attracted many powerful and well-known clients. Not shy of controversy, Liman represented junk bond merchant Michael Milken and corporate raider Carl Icahn. Adroit in corporate backrooms, he facilitated the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications.

Despite his success in private practice, Liman gained more notoriety as a result of his public assignments. Two appointments in particular defined his career. In 1972, he served as chief counsel of the New York State Special Commission on the Attica Prison uprising. The commission was charged with investigating the uprising at Attica State Prison in 1971 in which forty-three inmates and guards died. The commission's final report, which blamed prison conditions and state officials for the violence, was published in book form and nominated for a National Book Award. Liman's most widely-known assignment came in 1987 when he was appointed chief counsel to the Senate Select Committee on Secret Military Assistance to Iran and the Nicaraguan Opposition (the Iran-Contra Committee). The committee held hearings to make public the details of the clandestine operation selling weapons to Iran in exchange for the release of hostages and directing the arms proceeds to rebels in Nicaragua. The hearings, especially his cross-examination of Colonel Oliver North, put Liman in the national spotlight. The attention was not easy to bear, however, as the committee received criticism both for being too hard and too soft on witnesses and for its inability to trace knowledge of the operation to President Ronald Reagan.

Liman's public service extended beyond Attica and Iran-Contra. Among his other assignments were a 1979 suit in which he represented New York City against subway car manufacturers, winning a $72 million award, and heading the 1985 investigation of the New York City medical examiner amid charges that the examiner had provided false autopsy reports. In addition, he was active in organizations working to provide legal representation to those who could not afford it otherwise, serving terms as president of the Legal Aid Society and chairman of the Legal Action Center.
Arthur Liman married Ellen Fogelson, a writer, painter, and interior decorator, in 1959. They had three children: Lewis, Emily, and Douglas.
Arthur Liman died on July 17, 1997, in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains notes, correspondence, photocopies of legal documents, printed materials, photographs, and press clippings relating to Arthur Liman's legal career. This series is arranged alphabetically by subject or case name. The series includes material from both of Liman's best-known public service assignments, the committees to investigate the Attica State Prison uprising in 1972 and the Iran-Contra affair in 1987. Of particular interest are the diaries Liman kept on both occasions. In keeping with the original order of the collection, correspondence regarding specific cases resides in this series, although the bulk of the correspondence in this collection is in Series II. The scrapbooks in Series II contain more newspaper clippings regarding Attica State Prison and Iran-Contra. Series IV includes audiovisual material on Iran-Contra and Michael Milken.

Report on the New York City Medical Examiner
NYC/MTA R-46 [The City of New York and the New York City Transit Authority v. Pullman Incorporated, et al]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes correspondence, printed material, photographs, and press clippings arranged alphabetically. Routine correspondence from Arthur Liman's friends and colleagues, not specifically relating to a legal case, comprises a significant part of the series and is arranged chronologically. Letters of condolence received by Liman's family after his death in 1997 are arranged alphabetically according to the sender's last name. The series also includes biographical information and Liman's notes and papers from college and law school. The series concludes with scrapbooks, which consist largely of newspaper clippings and document Liman's time at Harvard and Yale and his work as chief counsel for the Attica and Iran-Contra committees.

did.unittitle: 1951-1977, n.d. [includes photographs and correspondence from Liman's time at Harvard and Yale, newspaper clippings about the Attica Prison uprising]
1971-1979, n.d. [includes newspaper clippings about the investigation of Attica, honors received by Liman]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains transcripts of Arthur Liman's speeches, copies of his written work, and select correspondence regarding his autobiography. It is arranged alphabetically by sections. The majority of the series consists of drafts of Liman's autobiography, Lawyer: A Life of Counsel and Controversy , published in 1998. Most of the correspondence is between Ellen Liman and Peter Israel, who served as an assistant on the autobiography. The series also includes a movie script and outline Liman wrote about Iran-Contra. Audio and videocassette recordings of some of Liman's speeches are included in Series IV.

did.unittitle: Lawyer: A Life of Counsel and Controversy [autobiography]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes audiotapes in cassette and microcassette format and videotapes in VHS and U-matic format. The series is arranged by format and chronologically within each format. The tapes in boxes 41, 42, and 43 are largely recordings of private conversations during Arthur Liman's Iran-Contra assignment and are the audiocassette tapes with the greatest research value. The tape in box 43 is the audio version of Liman's Iran-Contra diary, the transcript of which is in Series I. The majority of the microcassette tapes were recorded during the Iran-Contra hearings. The microcassette recordings capture Liman at his most candid regarding the Iran-Contra hearings and the Michael Milken sentence. The VHS videotapes in boxes 70, 72, 89, and 91 contain the most in-depth interviews of Liman.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiotapes and videotapes, as well as preservation masters and duplicating masters, may not be played. Consult the finding aid and/or a reference archivist to determine availability of a use copy or the process required to generate a use copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The addition consists of one piece of correspondence, one photograph, and publicity materials, mostly from the Arthur Liman Public Interest Fellowship and Fund.
